localize.description: See what's buzzing on The New York Times in your native language

These spiced pumpkin cookies are delightfully tender and moist, simple, and absolutely divine with a cup of coffee. â˜•ï¸ ğŸƒ
https://t.co/1n68Fxi2it
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: As a woman was being raped while on a train near Philadelphia on Wednesday night, riders watched, failed to intervene and did not call 911, the authorities said. https://t.co/IzbwLNrgTO
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Sister Megan Rice was a nun who was arrested more than 40 times for protesting Americaâ€™s military industrial complex, most spectacularly for breaking into one of the worldâ€™s largest uranium storage sites. She has died at age 91. https://t.co/lBA3pegFRN
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Breaking news: Robert Durst, 78, is on a ventilator in a Los Angeles hospital after testing positive for Covid-19, days after being sentenced to life in prison for murder, his lawyer said on Saturday. https://t.co/cB8MIrJngu
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: As Senator Joe Manchin blocks President Bidenâ€™s climate plan, new data shows that no state is more exposed to flood damage than his own. https://t.co/DsuRUGPZGc
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Former President Bill Clinton was released from a California hospital on Sunday after being admitted on Tuesday for treatment of a urological infection that developed into sepsis, officials said. https://t.co/sQaAyPyfGl
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: During the siege of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, seemingly average citizens â€” believing the lie that the 2020 presidential election was stolen â€” united in breathtaking acts of brutality. Amid a flash of violence, seven men from seven states stood out. https://t.co/xSQGXy9TmR
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Iztapalapa, the most populous neighborhood in Mexico City, has become a giant art gallery, blanketed with almost 7,000 pieces of commissioned public art commissioned by the government. But poverty and attacks against women are still pervasive in the area. https://t.co/Z3SdQ6xo25 https://t.co/OEsY9FhtSl
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Hereâ€™s how to make Dalgona Candy, or Ppopgi, the South Korean treat featured in an episode of the Netflix hit â€œSquid Game.â€  https://t.co/r7h8zC37mT
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: "Insecure" was only the second comedy created by and starring a Black woman when it debuted in 2016. Now in its final season, the show depicts its characters as authentically flawed. We spoke to creator and star Issa Rae about portraying vulnerability. https://t.co/OPQ0kJBxDX
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: All workers in Italy must be vaccinated against Covid-19 or take frequent coronavirus tests. Opponents of the measure tried to mount protests, but most Italians appeared to accept the rule as necessary. https://t.co/HqjneKYw7h https://t.co/GgU8T1AqWw
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: "Iâ€™m world famous for hiding in plain sight," says Questlove, the drummer, D.J. and producer who is everywhere and loved by everyone. But few understand what drives him: an obsession with spreading the joys of Black music. https://t.co/nojDuxgs6f
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
Breaking News: Gang members in Haiti kidnapped as many as 17 American missionaries and their family members as they were leaving an orphanage, Haitian officials said.
https://t.co/yrWqP7HiJ2
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
Part of the Catholic church in Sicily has imposed a three-year prohibition on naming godparents, arguing that the tradition has become merely a way to fortify family ties â€” and mob ties, too.
https://t.co/ASXmB51NZY
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: The habit of sea otters digging for food and disturbing eelgrass seems to make oceanic ecosystems more resilient, scientists found, highlighting the importance of restoring missing predators like sea otters to marine ecosystems. https://t.co/59uNWB53BU
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Bill Clinton has been hospitalized after he had a urological infection that developed into sepsis, an aide said on Thursday. The aide said it was not considered to be acute. https://t.co/z6GuVA0maU
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Illinois Democrats on Friday proposed a new set of highly gerrymandered congressional maps that would consolidate Democratic power in the stateâ€™s congressional delegation, most likely cutting the number of Republican seats in the state to three from five. https://t.co/BQRc67D01K
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Netflix fired an employee for leaking documents about Dave Chappelle's new special, which critics inside and outside the company have called transphobic. The comedian Hannah Gadsby on Friday rebuked the Netflix co-chief executive Ted Sarandos by name. https://t.co/m8KmXUQa4G
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Breaking News: The heart of President Biden's climate agenda â€” a push to replace coal- and gas-fired power plants â€” is said to likely be cut from the budget bill because Senator Joe Manchin opposes it. https://t.co/h73QT7NDpe
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Italy's requirement that all workers be vaccinated shows it is willing to use the full leverage of the state to try to curb the pandemic and get the economy moving. Most Italians accept it as a tolerable sacrifice. https://t.co/B2DOfeG1ku
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Hannah Gadsby publicly upbraided the Netflix CEO Ted Sarandos for citing her specials on the platform in his defense of Dave Chapelle, telling him not to "drag my name" into his justifications of "hate speech dog whistling you refuse to acknowledge." https://t.co/k244bKRBr4
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: A Texas school superintendent apologized to his district after one of his top officials advised teachers to "make sure that if you have a book on the Holocaust, that you have one that has an opposing, that has other perspectives." https://t.co/waMROVA2s7 https://t.co/27PhXmVqAF
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: "We recognize there are not two sides of the Holocaust." A Texas school superintendent apologized to his district after one of his top officials advised teachers that students learning about the Holocaust should have access to "opposing" perspectives. https://t.co/MTXjz1NUVq
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Breaking News: The Biden administration will ask the Supreme Court to block a Texas law that bars most abortions after six weeks of pregnancy while a challenge to it moves forward, a Justice Department spokesman said on Friday. https://t.co/G66G5JXVYd
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
Dave Chappelle's comments on transgender people and gender in his latest Netflix special, "The Closer," have led to outside criticism and internal unrest at the company.

"We'll continue to work with Dave Chappelle in the future," one executive said. https://t.co/DdDSUxh0n0
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
Port workers in Trieste, one of Italyâ€™s largest shipping and transport hubs, blocked access to the port in protest of the countryâ€™s new Covid health pass mandate that came into effect on Friday.
https://t.co/SRblzLXUG3
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
Breaking News: Fully vaccinated foreigners can enter the U.S. starting Nov. 8, a White House official said.
https://t.co/IuRfqayrYt
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
Ruth Hamilton was fast asleep when a 2.8-pound meteorite crashed through the ceiling of her home in British Columbia, landing between her pillows and barely missing her head.

â€œOh, my gosh,â€ she told the emergency operator, â€œthereâ€™s a rock in my bed.â€ https://t.co/zlEbrTWUVr https://t.co/7W7IrWWK0O

nodes.title:
Italy is requiring all workers to be vaccinated or take frequent coronavirus tests, the most sweeping mandate yet by a major Western democracy.
https://t.co/6brkTA5W6Q
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
Italy introduced a sweeping Covid vaccine mandate on Friday that requires the countryâ€™s entire work force to either be vaccinated or take a test every two days. Workers who do not meet the new requirements must take unpaid leave.

Follow updates here.
https://t.co/CT43phvhyo
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: A Texas man was sentenced to 23 years in federal prison on Wednesday for his connection in a scheme that used the dating app Grindr to target gay men for violent hate crimes, prosecutors said. https://t.co/TreNGvMF98
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
Bill Clinton has been hospitalized with a "non-Covid-related infection," a spokesman said on Thursday.
"He is on the mend, in good spirits and is incredibly thankful to the doctors, nurses, and staff providing him with excellent care," the spokesman added. https://t.co/5qZhYCyJO6
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
Dave Chappelle's comments on transgender people and gender in his latest Netflix special, "The Closer," have led to outside criticism and internal unrest at the company.

"We'll continue to work with Dave Chappelle in the future," one executive said. https://t.co/l8LZ3OCHHt
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
California recently became the first U.S. state to:
â€” Ban the sale of gas-powered lawn mowers
â€” Make the garment industry pay workers by the hour, instead of per item
â€” Require public high school students to take an ethnic studies course before graduating
https://t.co/zQ9EyiT4Y6
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Breaking News: Jeff Pash, the NFL's top lawyer, had a cozy relationship with a longtime president of the troubled Washington Football Team, emails show. Pash and the executive brokered penalties, discussed a cheerleading scandal and arranged perks. https://t.co/BYAuScv3FJ
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Lora Reinbold, a Republican state senator who was barred from Alaska Airlines flights after she refused to wear a mask, disclosed that she had tested positive for the coronavirus. https://t.co/deLx04emha
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: The Banksy painting that sensationally self-destructed three years ago after being sold at auction was resold by Sothebyâ€™s Thursday for 18.6 million pounds, or $25.4 million, a record for the artist. https://t.co/BwxkYZhd2F
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Andrew McCabe, a former FBI deputy director who was fired under Donald Trump, won back his pension and other benefits after settling a lawsuit against the Justice Department in which he asserted that he was dismissed for political reasons. https://t.co/UFGNsbvgIT
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Breaking News: The panel investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol will vote next week to recommend that Steve Bannon face criminal contempt charges for not complying with a subpoena. https://t.co/0k0ETI9gZR
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: The 25 largest orchestras in the U.S. have something in common: Not one is led by a woman. But that will change when Nathalie Stutzmann, a French conductor and singer, takes the Atlanta Symphony Orchestraâ€™s podium next year. https://t.co/UCvjgAWDtm
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: A Texas man was sentenced to 23 years in federal prison on Wednesday for his connection in a scheme that used the dating app Grindr to target gay men for violent hate crimes, prosecutors said. https://t.co/ANKagRezuy
nodes.author: The New York Times

â€œOh, my gosh,â€ she told the emergency operator, â€œthereâ€™s a rock in my bed.â€ https://t.co/OODcIuO614

nodes.title: Nicholas Kristof, after 37 years at The New York Times as a reporter, editor and opinion columnist, is leaving the newspaper as he considers running for governor of Oregon, the state where he grew up. https://t.co/0mVig79bFP
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Kyrie Irving, an NBA player for the Brooklyn Nets, spoke out publicly for the first time since the team barred him from the court because of his refusal to get the Covid-19 vaccine. He said his decision was a matter of personal freedom. https://t.co/8NcVFDSwIm
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Blue Origin wants to go to the moon, build larger rockets and, according to Jeff Bezos, eventually move all polluting industries off Earth and into space. https://t.co/UepXabskmB
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
In Opinion

@RGay writes about Dave Chappelle's new Netflix special: "Many of Chappelleâ€™s rants are extraordinarily dated, the kind of comedy you might expect from a conservative boomer, agog at the idea of homosexuality." https://t.co/f7AQpLjeTa
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Breaking News: A man reported to be armed with a bow and arrow went on a rampage in a Norwegian town on Wednesday, killing and wounding several people, the authorities said. This is a developing story. https://t.co/J3g5njispo

nodes.title: Ruthie Tompson, who worked on nearly every one of Disney's animated features over four decades, including "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," "Pinocchio" and "Dumbo," has died at 111. https://t.co/z3N0UBwPDf
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: With the Senate out of session, Senator Kyrsten Sinema, the moderate Arizona Democrat who has objected to the size and scope of President Biden's sweeping legislative agenda, has been in Europe on a fund-raising trip. https://t.co/YbNeHMwKQ2
nodes.author: The New York Times
